titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Morning visit from Mr: Navarro. He has no recent intelligence of material moment. He brought me an official copy of the Treaty of Alliance between Portugal and Russia, the 21st: Article of which, is omitted in the Treaty as published by Martens in his Collection— This Article limited the duration of the Treaty to eight years from the exchange of the Ratifications. I took a short walk before dinner, and a long one after, in which I was overtaken by Rain— It gave me a Cold in the midst of my regimen— Mr: Smith dined abroad. In the Evening I read a number of Porter’s letters; which I still find amusing; and they are remarkably easy to read.— The descriptions of the objects which he saw in this Country are generally accurate, and from a hand still more accustomed to paint than to write— Difficile est communia proprie dicere, says Horace, if I remember right— In my family letters I often feel the embarrassment of telling with propriety trivial things: and in these letters of Porter, I find myself forestalled upon many subjects upon which I intended to write. I have however given to my Mother an account of the Easter-Holidays.

2. Mr: Benedict Cramer paid me a visit this morning, for the purpose of explaining to me the Circumstances, under which he was induced the last Autumn to give his opinion in the case of the sugars imported from the Havanna— He complained that he had been in the first instance misled by Baron Campenhausen— That his opinion had afterwards been misrepresented, and finally that artifice had been used to suppress the explanation and apology for his conduct which he had given— Baron Campenhausen had sent for him; and on his going he had found with him Mr: P. Severin, the foreman of his sugar refinery, and a Clerk of the Custom-house— The Baron had shewn him some specimens of sugars, saying that they had been imported in a vessel called Die Freundschaft, a German name, and that they came from England— Mr: Heimburger, Mr: Severin’s foreman holding up some of the Sugar said there was not a boy in the Streets of Hamburg, but could pronounce
them on bare inspection to be crushed lumps. All the other persons present agreed to this opinion, and as it appeared to be the Baron’s determination so to consider them, it was dangerous to express a doubt upon the subject— Nevertheless that he Mr: Cramer, with regard to one or two of the specimens not only had his doubts, but both from the Appearance and smell of the sugar had taken it to be white Havanna, and had said so at the time.— Afterwards Mr: Andrews had spoken and complained to him of the opinion he had given— He had offered to Mr: Andrews to do every thing in his power to rectify the mistake, and to remove the difficulties with the Government here, which had been occasioned by it; but Mr: Andrews had been exasperated, and refused his assistance— Since then, Mr: Wallis, Super Cargo of a vessel at Archangel had written to him that he had been directed to consign his Cargo to the House of Cramer, but having been informed that he had taken part against the Americans upon the question concerning the sugars, he had felt it his duty to address himself to another house— He had written a long letter of explanation, and to justify himself to Mr: Wallis, to which that Gentleman had not thought proper to give any answer— And as by the reports which had been circulated against him the house had thus already been injured and might be still more so, he had called upon Baron Campenhausen, and requested him to certify to me his Mr Cramer’s opinion as he had really given it— The Baron had asked him what he could do for him? It was impossible to expect he would write any thing contrary to the opinion he had heretofore given; but he finally promised, when he should see me to speak to me upon the subject, and to tell me what opinion Mr: Cramer had really given; and Mr: Cramer’s request to me was, that if Baron Campenhausen should perform this promise, of which he would take care to have him again reminded, and any occasion should occur when I could correct the misrepresentations which had gone abroad against him, I would so far befriend him; which I readily promised— I told him that I had heard much of this business at the time when it was in discussion, and had been under the necessity of speaking to Count Romanzoff about it— But I had never said any thing of it to Baron Campenhausen, and the Correspondence had all been managed by Mr: Harris— I had indeed been surprized and mortified on hearing that he and Mr: Severin had concurred in giving an opinion which might have occasioned the confiscation of a large property belonging to Countrymen of mine, upon suspicions which I had no doubt were groundless, but Mr: Severin had never mentioned the subject to me, nor I to him. I was glad however to hear his explanation, and should be happy to contradict any misstatement of his conduct if any proper occasion for it should present itself— He told me that he had given an explanation entirely satisfactory to Mr: Dana, who had formed a commercial connection with his house— This Circumstance had been mentioned to me by Mr: Harris, who had been not a little chagrined at it; though I believe he must impute it to himself.— I dined at Count St: Julien’s; with a small Company— General Ouvaroff and General Pardo— Mr: Laval and Mr: Ribaupierre—with Mr: Schubert the Director of the Academy of Sciences, and the Count’s Secretaries Lebzaltern and Berks— The Count apologized for a departure from etiquette in having sent Cards of invitation for an unceremonious dinner— His other guests had been as much perplexed as General Pardo and myself, to know how they should go dressed— At dinner the Count mentioned his having been last Evening at Countess Strogonoff’s, and suddenly having found out that the Princess Amelia of Baden was there— Upon which Mr: Laval told an anecdote, of a person who once met the same Princess at the same house— While they were there the Princess asked if her Sister (the Empress) had not pass’d by in a Carriage; and the Gentleman had answered, “I dont know, but if you will tell me her name I will go and see.”— Ah! said Count St: Julien that must have been a stranger like one of us.— No said Mr: Laval—very far from it—quite another person—but he did not name him— So that it was not explained whether it was an instance of ignorance or of insolence— But at any rate it marks the tone of treatment which both the Empress and her Sister meet at this Court.— I had after dinner much conversation with Mr: Laval, who says that the War is not so near as is pretended, and confirmed me in the opinion I had that many of the current war rumours are invented by the party who are labouring to plunge the Emperor into the War, offensively.— Laval says the Emperor sees this as clearly as he or I do, and that he will not be guided by that party— In the Evening I paid a visit to Madame de Betancourt and her daughters— The General was not at home— While I was there Mr: Harris came in— Closed the Evening at home, without reading or writing.

3. I received this morning from Riga, a large packet containing dispatches from the Department of State—that is, the National Intelligencer from 8 December 1809 to 2 March 1810 and a number of documents printed at Washington, during that Session of Congress— They are doubtless the dispatches carried by Mr: Sims from Gothenburg to Hamburg, and forwarded from that place by Mr: Forbes.— Mr: Consolat came and brought me an account of some further transactions for Mr: Gray. I attended at an
auction of Books, but made no purchases— Mr: Harris spent part of the Evening with us— I read a number more of Porter’s letters, and finished the Moniteurs lent me by the French Ambassador— He called to visit me this morning but I was abroad.

4. I received this morning a letter of about five lines from Lieutt: Governor Gray dated 19. Feby: last, and one of 20 Feby: from his Clerk Mr Gordon, still shorter— They came by the Washington arrived at Revel, and I am afraid are the only letters from America which we shall receive by that opportunity— I continued engaged writing all the morning— Short walk before dinner, and a longer one after it— In the latter I twice met Count Lüxbourg, with Messieurs Rayneval and Prevost, who informed me that the new Ambassador, Count Lauriston had not yet arrived, but had pass’d through Dantzick and by a letter from Prince Labanoff was expected at Riga— This Evening I finished reading Porter’s letters;—the only valuable parts of which are his descriptions of visible objects which occurred to his observation— His politics, are full of English prejudices, his gallantry is vapid, his military enthusiasm ridiculous, his adoration of kings, princess, Empresses, and Queens shallow and vain, & his heroics a burlesque. When he sticks to his brush, he is amusing and accurate.

5. Morning visit from the Chevalier Brancia, the Neapolitan Chargé des Affaires— He has been long very much out of health, and still looks very ill; but says the approach of Spring is restoring him— He mentioned to me the news that the Duke de Cadore was removed from the Office of Minister of foreign Affairs at Paris, and the Duke de Bassano, Maret, appointed to it— He spoke to me of a History of the War of American Independence lately published in Italian by Botta, and spoken of as an excellent work. He said he hoped soon to receive it, end would lend it to me. In my walk before dinner I met and walked with Count Lüxbourg, who repeated to me the news from France with the addition that Count Daru is the Minister Secretary of State in the room of Maret— Lüxbourg had also, some other information; but he thinks the War still inevitable. I walked again after dinner, and met Mr: Krehmer and Count Bose— I was writing great part of the day to the Secretary of State; but in the Evening read Massillon’s discourse, on the advantages of retirement to Curates, a subject like that which I read last Sunday, already treated in one of the Discourses of the former volume— I read also Sections 13 & 14. of Robinson’s character of Jesus Christ.— My worldly occupations still make me carry too much of the week into the Sabbath.— Mr Smith spent the day in the Country.

6. Morning visit from Mr: Raimbert, who complains much of the accounts furnished by Mr: Rodde of Revel, upon Mr: Gray’s vessels that have wintered there and are coming to Cronstadt— He told me also that he had just come from the Ambassador’s: that he hoped there would be no War— That they were afraid here— I afterwards paid a visit to the Ambassador myself and found him at home— He enquired if I had any recent accounts of the State of our affairs with France or England— I told him all I had heard—and said that after the Emperor Napoleon’s declaration in the answer to the deputation from Hamburg, Lubeck and Bremen, all we could do would be to wait with patience— The Emperor said that the decrees of Berlin and Milan for all Nations that did not support their flag, against the British Orders in Council— The British would not revoke them— We had nothing left to maintain our flag but War— And in a War with England, we should have no flag— When we have two hundred ships of the line, and a navy in proportion we may talk of maintaining our flag by War— Now, it would be ridiculous— He said he wished it were possible to see a prospect of Peace— I observed that according to general opinion it was more remote than ever— Though I understood the hope of preserving Peace between France and Russia was now stronger than some time ago— Oh! Oui! said he— J’espere que tout cela se civilisera— I do not see any great interests upon which the two Countries need to quarrel; nor even any small interests which may not easily be arranged to their mutual satisfaction. And then he repeated j’espere que tout cela se civilisera— I asked him if he expected General Lauriston soon to arrive—he answered to day, or to-morrow.— Indeed he might have been here before this— A Courier who arrived three days ago left him at Dantzick.— I said [“]I had heard that there had been a change in the Department of Foreign Affairs in France—that the Duke de Cadore was no longer the Minister”— “It was true— The Minister appointed in his place was the Duke de Bassano[”]— I remarked that he had been long and constantly engaged in public Affairs, and Secretary, I believe ever since the Executive Council— The Ambassador said I was mistaken— That the Secretary under the Directory was La Garde, and Maret came in only at the time of the Consulate— He did not know what was the occasion of the Duke de Cadore’s going out— It was only mentioned to him in a private letter of 16. April, the day when it happened, and when the Courier was to have left Paris— I asked if it would probably produce any material change in the political system— No— The Emperor governs so much by himself, that a Minister is nothing more than the pen, and not the hand that guides it— I asked if the Prince of Benevento had not still some Superintendance over the department of foreign affairs— No— He had no hand in the public affairs at present; but was altogether in retirement— His capacity as a Grand-Dignitaire was that of Vice-Grand-Elector, the double, of the king of Spain, who was Grand-Elector. This was a place not of
business, but merely of Representation— Its only duty was to present to the Emperor the Senators, and members of the Legislative Body. The only Office of a diplomatic Nature, in Rank above that of the Minister of Exterior Relations was the Arch-Chancellor of State; which was held by the Vice-Roy of Italy.— I asked him whether he expected to go, soon after the arrival of his Successor— He said in three or four days— That he had had full time to be prepared, and should be impatient to get home— I asked him if he would do me the favour to take a small packet of letters for Mr: Russell, which he promised to do with pleasure— He said that shortly before his departure he would give me notice, and call to take leave of Mrs Adams— From his house I went to visit Mr Laval, but did not find him at home.— I then called upon Mr: Wiggers heretofore the Agent from the Hanseatic Cities, and returned him the French History of that League which he lent me last Summer, and which I have kept from that time— I had a long conversation with him— He does not believe in a War with France for the present year. After this visit I dismissed my Carriage, and walked round by the Fontanka home— I met the Emperor who stop’d and conversed with me: at first as usual about the weather, which he remarked was warmer and finer he said than he remembered ever to have known it, so early in the season— But he was afraid we should have it balanced by foul weather hereafter— Snow, it was at least certain we should have—for he had never known, and there never had been known here an instance of a month of May passing entirely without Snow— I said that now the weather was rather that of an Italian Spring— He remarked that it was very long since he had seen me, and asked if I had abandoned my habit of walking— I answered that I had not, but I believed that it was the hour at which I usually walked that deprived me of the happiness of meeting his Majesty— He said that he had often of late been so engaged in business that he could not take his usual walks; and sometimes he had gone out of the usual track, which might also have contributed to the length of time since he had met me— He then said the Ice from the Ladoga was passing down, (he was coming from the river—I was going towards it) but that there was not much of it, and the weather was so moderate he thought there would not be so much as usual— He then made a movement as if to leave me, and I was about to bow and turn from him, when he step’d back to me and leaning on the iron-railing of the Canal asked me if I had any late accounts from home— I told him I had letters to the 20th: of February— He asked if they contained information of any particular importance?— I said they did not— That the occurrence of principal note of which I had heard was the arrival of the new French Minister, Serrurier, to replace the former one General Turreau— He asked me what the state of our Affairs with England was— I— answered that they remained in an unsettled state— That our Minister there had taken leave and was gone; but he had left a Chargé des Affaires there; and that the English Government had sent out a new Minister to the United States, who as Mr: Perceval had said in Parliament carried out some new propositions from England— I added that I had heard Mr: Smith, a Gentleman who had been with me, and had had the honour of being presented to his Majesty, would be chargé d’Affaires in England— But, said the Emperor, did not he go from here to Vienna? I said he did; and was now at Paris— But I had heard he was to be the Chargé d’Affaires in England— It is a place of some importance, said His Majesty, is it not?— I said of very considerable importance—especially in the present state of the relations between the United States, and England— And, said he, I hear you have lately made an acquisition— I observed, I supposed his Majesty meant in Florida—he said that was what he meant— But said he, it appears to have been a spontaneous movement of the People themselves, who were desirous of joining themselves to the United States— I said, so it appeared from the accounts which I had seen, but that I had received no Communication from my Government upon this subject— I added that this was a part of the Territory which had been ceded by France to the United-States in the Louisiana Treaty— That Spain however had entered into a controversy with us about it, upon which Negotiations were pending at the time when the great changes in the Government of Spain itself had taken place— That since then the People of that Country had been left in a sort of abandonment by Spain, and must naturally be very desirous of being annexed to the United-States—under these Circumstances the United States have taken possession of the Country— The Emperor smiled and said “on s’aggrandit toujours un peu, dans ce Monde”—and bowed; upon which I quitted him and continued my walk.— We had been standing so long that numbers of People between the two Bridges had observed us, and from the time when I left him, untill I had got beyond the distance where we could be seen together, the people gazed upon me as upon a very important personage— Once pass’d those boundaries every Moozhik brushed by me with as little notice, as if passing one of his fellows— Such is the Magic of an Emperor’s countenance— We had stood all the time immediately before the guard of Soldiers stationed upon the Fontanka; who were turned out under arms— When he turn’d back to me, to speak of politics he waved his hand to the Officer to dismiss the guard from being under arms, which he did— when I came to the river, I found the Ice passing down as he had told me, and in small quantities— There was more in the
Evening at 8 and 9 O’Clock, when I went to the warm Water Bath (Grootten’s) and returned from it. I am yet doubtful of the effects of this species of ablution.

7. I had an indifferent Night after the Bath, and was not very well this day.— The Black Man in the Emperor’s service, Claude Gabriel for whose wife and children I wrote the last Autumn to America, came to enquire if I had received any answer— When I read to him the passage of Mr: Gray’s letter which leaves it doubtful whether she would consent to come, he appeared to be much affected, and tears started in his eyes.— He said if she would not come he could not help it— He would stay here.— I had visits from Mr Plummer, with Captain Larcom of the Thetis, a vessel at Revel, going to Boston, and from Mr: Lohman and Mr: Harris— Mr: Lohman is going to Revel and Riga, and offered to take letters for me— While Mr: Harris was with me, I received from Count Romanzoff a large Packet brought by a Russian Courier, from Mr: Russell at Paris— It contained a pamphlet from Mr: Maclure, a letter from Mr: Russell and one from my Son George, and several other letters from Mr: J. S. Smith to W. S. Smith— Nothing new from America— I had a very short walk before dinner— The weather was at summer heat—in the morning the river was so full of the ice from the Ladoga that Captain Larcom had found it difficult to come over in a boat from the Island— Between 4 and 5 when I walked the Ice had all pass’d down, and the river was entirely clear— In the Evening I took a long walk—the weather was still fine as in Summer— Met and walked with Count Lüxbourg and Mr: Prevost— This Gentleman told me that Coll: Kablukoff the Russian Courier had pass’d General Lauriston on this side of Memel— That he would stop one day at Riga— That his Secretary was expected to arrive this Evening or to-morrow, and the General himself a day later— After I came home I read some pages of Carr.

8. I sent this morning to Mr: Lohman a packet for the Secretary of State, and one for Quincy, to be delivered at Revel to Captain Avery of the Iris, and to Captain Stanly of the William.— Received a letter from Mr: Preuss at Liebau; he expected very shortly to go over to Carlshamm.— My morning walk was short—and the Evening walk long. After returning home I finished reading the second volume of Carr—a great dealer in trifles.

9. On rising this morning I received from the French Ambassador a message that his successor Count Lauriston had arrived in the Night; and an invitation to come and dine with him—in boots. After writing untill 3. O’Clock, excepting the interval of an hour when I had visits from the Chevalier de Navarro and Mr Harris, I walked, and met Count Schenk in the Newsky Perspective— He turned about and walked with me; we walked round by the Fontanka to the Summer Gardens, through which we pass’d to return home; he told me that his new Secretary a Mr: Grümp had arrived the day before yesterday; but having had the misfortune to overset, he had got his face too much bruised to be presented as yet— He said he hoped he would be of more service to him than his predecessor Mülinen had been—for excepting to assist him a little in cyphering he had been of no use to him at-all— The Count himself talked to me upon this walk in a style which gave me no good opinion of him— At half past four I went to the French Ambassador’s and dined. He presented us to General Count Lauriston, a man, by his own account as near as may be, of my age—very different in manners, address and appearance from the Duke de Vicence. The comparison is not to his advantage— He brought with him an Aid de Camp named Longuerue, who appeared only at the dinner; was introduced to nobody and spoke to nobody— The Company besides the two Ambassadors and the family, consisted of Counts St: Julien, Schenk and Bussche, and Lüxbourg— General Pardo and Baron Blome, the Chevalier Brancia and myself— Prince Galitzin was the only Russian there— The Duke de Vicence was suffering excessive pain with his lame leg and foot— While we were at dinner Count Tolstoi the Grand Marshall came in full dress from Court to pay his visit to the new Ambassador— Mr d’Alopeus came in after dinner, and said he was going upon his mission in a very few days.— There was in the Evening a play at the Hermitage, it being the celebration of the Grand Duke Constantine’s birth-day— Count Bussche remarked that the choice of the plays was made by the Emperor, and it was singular that for this Evening he had selected Ruse contre Ruse—the other title of which is Guerre ouverte— After the dinner I walked about an hour with Count Lüxbourg, who still thinks the War will break out— Coming home I met Mr: Borel.— Evening idle.

10. I had an uneasy and sleepless Night; Mrs Adams being quite unwell, and my own anxiety very great— The day was foul so that I was confined all the morning to the house— I rose at 5 in the morning, and employed all the day untill dinner time, writing.— Dined at Baron Blome’s with both the French Ambassadors and their families— Mr: and Madame Lesseps and their daughter were there— Count Bussche, General Watzdorf, Mr: d’Alopeus, Count Lüxbourg and the Chevalier Brancia constituted the remainder of the Company.
After dinner I paid a visit to Mr: Krehmer’s where there were several English Gentlemen— Came home early in the Evening— Mr: Bridge paid us a two hours visit.

11. I slept the last Night for two, and did not rise this morning untill near ten O’Clock— The consequence of which was that I had not finished my regular Morning’s reading, when I was called to breakfast. Before I returned to my Closet, I received a note from Mr: Krehmer, with a file of English Newspapers from 20. March to 9. April— Mr: Plummer called upon me and amused himself an hour or two in reading the Papers— Mr: Montreal came, and gave me some account of the proceedings and difficulties in the execution of Mr. Gray’s orders— I skimm’d over as rapidly as I could the English papers, and the french and German ones which came by this day’s Post— It was half-past four O’Clock, and I had not written a line— A great number of my days pass much in this way— I postponed the finishing of my letter untill to-morrow—and took a very short walk before dinner.— After dinner I went to the German Play and saw Kotzebue’s Bayard— I had read it in America, and felt some curiosity to see it. The performance was indifferent— The characters are all grotesque exaggerations—the intrigue all romance—the sentiments bombastic, and the play, altogether, though a deep Tragedy, cold and flat. It contains some historical incidents, and particularly that of Bayard’s death under the tree.

12. I finished this forenoon, the letter which had remained incomplete since the day before yesterday. It rained almost the whole morning, so that I was able only to take a walk of about half an hour— It is the third day in succession that my usual walks have been interrupted— Count Schenk paid me a morning visit to introduce his new Secretary of Legation Mr Gremp— Mr. Harris dined and spent part of the Evening with us— I sent to invite Mr: Navarro to dine with us— He was engaged, but came and spent an hour with us in the Evening— I read Massillon’s Discourse upon the zeal of the Clergy for the Salvation of Souls, & Robinson’s Sections 15 and 16. of the character of Jesus-Christ— The day is not yet sufficiently devoted to its duties.—

13. Russian May-day. The weather was cold and in the morning rainy— I wrote to my brother— We dined at 4. O’Clock, and after dinner the ladies went to the procession of Carriages from the Peterhoff gate to Catherinenhoff— I took a long walk round the Fontanka, and river Quay; over the Bridge which was yesterday replaced, to the new Exchange— I met in the Newsky Perspective, Baron Campenhausen, who turned and walked to the Fontanka Bridge with me— He had called upon me the day before yesterday when I had not been at home— He said it was to talk to me about a poor merchant, one Mr: Cramer, whom he had sent for to take his opinion last Autumn about some sugars at Archangel, and who together with other persons whom he had also called to give their opinions had taken them for refined sugars, powdered— That he had lately been to him and complained that this affair had injured him exceedingly— That Mr: Harris had written to America charging him with having taken part against the Americans, and it had affected him very seriously in his business— That Mr: Cramer had requested him to speak to me about it; and he could assure me that Mr: Cramer had no knowledge whatsoever that it was sugar imported by Americans; which must acquit him of any intention to injure Americans in their trade— I told the Baron that Mr Cramer had spoken to me on this subject and that I had heard a great deal of it, at the time while the character of the sugars was in question— That several Americans had indeed at the time been much alarmed on finding themselves suspected and inculpated of an intended fraud upon the Government; and when they found such charges and suspicions countenanced by an opinion said to have been delivered by Mr. Cramer, when consulted by the Government, it was natural that they should feel resentment against him, and that it should have affected him in his business— Mr: Cramer had told me however not only that he had not known the sugars to be the property of Americans, but that he had been of a different opinion from that of the other persons consulted, with respect to a part of the Samples. This fact was more material to his justification, than whether he did or did not know to whom the property belonged, and this was what he had told me the Baron would attest for him— The Baron said it was true Mr Cramer had at first expressed a doubt with regard to one of the samples, but he as well as the other Gentlemen had finally assented to the opinion of the sugar-refiner, who came from Hamburg— That, I said was the misfortune, as it was now ascertained that they were all mistaken, and the sugar refiner as much as all the rest— The sugars were raw white Havanna, and not refined sugar powdered— Mr: Cramer with the other Gentlemen had made a mistake unfortunate now for himself, but with regard to the intention I believed he was not to blame, and if the
occasion should offer I would say as much in his favour.— Upon this I left the Baron and continued my walk.— The whole of this transaction has proved to me the evil and the danger of excessive jealousy and suspicion in the management of public business— The Baron himself was the dupe of his own suspicions— He endeavoured in a cunning way to get the opinions of merchants to sanction his suspicions. He succeeded to get the opinion, but it was an error; its effect was almost to ruin one of the merchants from whom he had drawn an incautious and mistaken opinion, and now he is reduced to exculpate the man, whom he injured by a captious and insidious consultation— He says he refused to tell them to whom the sugars belonged— Cramer says he deceived them by using German names to designate American vessels— Under the semblance of an impartial examination, it was an unfair snare laid for the merchants whom he consulted, as well as for the importers whose property was at stake— And all to indulge suspicions— Give me, in every station of life, and every crisis of affairs an open and a candid mind— At the new Exchange I saw the progress of the square and the semi-circular quay in its front; and for the first time the Colossal figures to be placed at the sides of the rostral columns— They are not yet finished— On returning home I found a Card from the Duke of Vicence to take leave; and one from the Comte de Lauriston announcing himself, as Ambassador Extraordinary from France.— Mr: Woodward called upon us, having returned last Evening from Liebau— The two French Ambassadors paid the Ladies a visit in person— The Duke de Vicence had his Diamond Star on which was presented him by the Emperor.

14. Mr: Harris called on me this morning, somewhat agitated and much displeased that one of the Cards of the new Ambassador, Count Lauriston had not been sent to him; and he declared his determination to complain of it to Count Romanzoff. He considered it as a piece of misconduct in the Master of Ceremonies, Mr Maisonneuve, to have omitted his name from the list, as such Cards had always been sent to him before— I received a note from Mr: Fisher, with a collection of Rubles from the time of Peter 1.— At 2 O’Clock I went in Ceremony to pay the first visit to the French Ambassador, but he was not at home.— At 4. I went to dinner at Count Romanzoff’s. The usual diplomatic company— The Duke de Vicence glittered in his diamond star, and still more magnificent eagle, suspended to the blue ribband, of the order of St: Andrew.— Count Lauriston has only the great ribband of the order of the iron-crown; a yellow ribband with dark green borders— The Duke de Richelieu was of the Company.— After returning home I took a long walk— Met and walked half an hour with General Watzdorf— Met also Mr: Brancia walking, and Baron Blome in his Droshka. Mr: Plummer was with us at the close of the Evening and took my dispatches and letters for Captain Larcom of the Thetis— He is going to-morrow to embark at Revel for Boston.

15. It was eleven O’Clock this morning when I rose— Heavy rain all the first part of the day— Mr: Fisher paid me a visit— I weighed his collection of Rubles, and found most of the variations in the Laws from the time of Peter I. in 1718. down to the present time. I wasted the morning in trivial occupation— After dinner I walked to the foundery— Mr: Harris spent the Evening with us.

16. Mr: Dana, who returned a day or two since from Moscow called on me this morning; and while he was here Mr: Raimbert and Mr: Montréal came, very much alarmed at the news from America, contained in the Hamburg Gazette— The new non-importation act, and the sale of English prizes at Charleston taken by french privateers— My intention was to have paid some visits this morning, but as it happens nine times in ten the time slip’d away untill it was too late, and yet I had done nothing. I walked to the Cazan Church, and thence through the Summer Gardens to the river and back by the admiralty.— After dinner I renewed the walk, and at the Gate of the Summer-Garden took Charles with me and walked with him there— He was on Old May-day put into full boys cloathes— Returning home I saw the setting Sun, from my usual stand. it sunk in a direct line behind the westernmost of the two rostral columns upon the half rotundo in front of the exchange— Evening at home reading Bagatelles—

17. Mr. Harris called on me this morning, and requested me to go with him to present him to the new French Ambassador; he was not at home, and we left Cards there, and at M: de Caulaincourt’s— He has removed into the apartments on the Street, leaving all the Hotel on the Canal to his successor— We next went to Count Schenk’s, where we were received; but his Secretary M. de Gremp whose visit I was returning was not at home. As we left Count Schenk’s the new french Ambassador drove up to the door in his Carriage and left a Card without getting out— He pass’d me immediately afterwards and I saw that he was full dress’d— On leaving Count Schenk’s I parted from Mr: Harris,
and called at Count Stedingk’s, but he was not at home— I walked round upon the river Quay, and through the Summer-Gardens, where I found some elegant Company— The Bridge to Kammenoi-Ostroff is just putting up for the summer— On returning home, I found the Ambassador’s Cards— He had been going through one of the most inconvenient and absurd, but best established usages of this place— That of going a round of visits in full Court dress; and leaving Cards at every house, without enquiring whether the persons visited are at home, or ever getting out of the Carriage— There is so much punctilio in this usage, that it admits of no substitute— It is not sufficient to send a servant with a Card, nor even to send round your Carriage— Nay, if you go yourself, unless it be in full dress, the visit is not duly paid— You must be seen in full dress by all the Porters; but it is understood that you are only to leave a Card— This is called a diplomatic visit paid in person— I walked again in the Evening— Met and walked with General Pardo, a phenomenon of human character— An excellent classical scholar; a profound Connoisseur in the Arts— A Spaniard the proudest of his Nation that I ever knew; a most impassioned Spanish Patriot, in their present struggle against France, and yet, appearing here as the Minister of King Joseph. a Lieutenant General by his appointment; and wearing a great “blushing ribband” of his order— He is of all the men that I was ever acquainted the one whose discourse is the most constantly in hostility with his situation and conduct— Yet his conversation is agreeable— His great intellectual deficiency is judgment— His characteristic want is energy— Such a composition is rare— Taste, Learning, and a brilliant imagination, without steadiness of brain or firmness of heart.— He told me the Duke de Vicence would go to-morrow night.

18. Morning visit from Mr: Montréal, and afterwards from Mr: Harris, who came to tell me that he should call with the Duke de Richelieu, which he did about an hour after— The Duke is Governor of Odessa, and now here upon a visit, as he has been about six weeks— He is of the antient and high nobility of the french monarchy, and was an emigrant; but has been many years in the Russian service.— He told me that he had an army list of France for the year 1790—in which the Emperor Napoleon, Count Lauriston, and Savary were all down, as second lieutenants in the regiment of La Fere— He spoke to me also of the American trade to the Black Sea, and wished that the admission of American vessels to it might be stipulated in the Treaty of Peace between Russia and the Porte; to which he supposed the Turks would readily agree, and which he was only afraid would be forgotten— After a short morning walk I went and dined at Baron Blome’s with a Company of fifty persons— It was a great diplomatic dinner in full state; given to the New Ambassador; and attended by the usual company of Generals and Ministers— There was a band of music which performed during the whole dinner time— Genl: Pardo told me that he did not like music at dinner— It was too heating— The Duke de Vicence, and Mr: Rayneval were not there. The Duke was too much engaged in his preparations for departure— I spoke to Count Romanzoff at Mr: Harris’s request; desiring him to urge the publication by the Senate of the Ukaze, recognizing Mr: Dana, as American Vice-Consul at Archangel— The Count said he would bear it in mind and do what he could; but there was a routine in these publications of the Senate, which moved very slow, and was not easy to quicken. He had known it in several instances, and particularly in the case of a French Consul.— The dinner was short and I came home about seven in the Evening. I was from that time employed untill near midnight, in preparing a packet to send by the Duke de Vicence to Mr: Russell the American Chargé d’Affairs at Paris— The Duke sent me word about nine that he should go very early in the morning, and would take what I wished to send— Mr: Smith was out, and as I could not close my packet untill he returned I walked from nine to ten— He soon after came in, and I closed and sent my packet to the Duke shortly before Midnight.

19. The morning being fine, and as on rising I heard the music of one of the regiments marching to the Parade, I resolved to go out and see it— I went about half past eight O’Clock, but found only one regiment yet upon the square— Pursued my walk to the Quay where I met the Chevalier Brancia; he turned and we walked to the summer Gardens— On our return we found the troops all assembled, and the servants with horses waiting at the Emperor’s door— Walked round the Boulevard, when Brancia left me— He was going to visit Dr: Crichton— A few minutes before ten the Emperor appeared; galloping along in front of the line of troops which extended from the Corner of the Grand Millionne to the Bridge across the Nicolai Canal on the Galeeren-hoff— The Grand-Duke Constantine, rode at the Emperor’s left hand, on a line with him— The French Ambassador, Count St: Julien, and General Watzdorf followed behind, and a suite of fifteen or twenty General-Officers and Aid de Camps— I could not ascertain the
number of the troops upon the parade— There was a mixture of Infantry, Cavalry and Artillery— I marked the Hulon Regiment, every man of whom carries a little red and white pennant at the top of his pike.— The arrangement of baggage appears well adapted for marches, and to diminish the incumbrances of a large train— The Emperor’s review is not long— It consists in his galloping from one end to the other of the line, and back again— After which the troops file off on the palace Square before him— I came home about 11. O’Clock, much fatigued— Mr: Harris soon after called upon me with some very important and mysterious news from America contained in the English Newspapers, which Count Romanzoff has received— But as I laughed a little at what he first told me, he reserved the rest which had more probability— He afterwards came & dined with us.— After dinner we rode with the Ladies and Charles to Kammenoi Ostroff, and saw the earliest appearances of vegetation. Returned home about 9 in the Evening; that is, just at Sunset— I read Massillon’s discourse on the Zeal of the Ministers of God against Vice— It is a sequel to that which I had read last Sunday— The characters of this Zeal, the Bishop says, should be those by which St: Paul designates Charity— And he enlarges upon each of them separately—the Discourse is accordingly very long— read also Robinson’s Character of Christ—Sections 17 and 18.

20. I walked this morning before breakfast and measured the distance from the Corner of the Grande Millionne opposite the Winter Palace, to the Bridge over the Nicolai Canal on the Galeeren Hoff; being the space usually covered by the troops at the Reviews, on Sundays— It is a 30 minutes walk; equivalent to one mile and three quarters or about 9000 feet— Allowing two feet space for each man it would form therefore a line of four thousand five hundred men— Soon after Breakfast I received from Mr: Krehmer the English Couriers to 19. April, and found in them the news which had alarmed Mr: Harris, together with an Article which he had not mentioned, but which alarmed my wife. It renews the uncertainty of condition in which I have lived nearly these five months—but which cannot much longer continue— Mr: Bridge and Mr: Jones paid me a visit—the former going to Revel to-morrow, left with me his Passport, to be certified, which I did and sent it to him in the Evening. Mr: Jones arrived yesterday from Moscow— I went with Mr: Harris and returned the Duke de Richelieu’s visit at the Hotel du Nord, but he was not at his lodgings. Miss Clémentine de Bode dined with us.— I was employed all the leisure of the day in reading the English Papers— In the Evening we had Cards.

21. Mr: Montreal called on me this morning, with a minute of drafts and purchases made on account of Mr: Gray— I paid a visit to Mr: Navarro, and while I was with him Mr: Schenbom came in— He told a number of anecdotes about Count Pahlen, the father of the Russian Minister in America, and about some other Russian noblemen— Pahlen he says when a very young man was sent as a Courier to Stockholm— And being dispatched by the Minister there, on his return, with orders to go with the utmost possible speed, he could not come, with Post-Horses, having lost all the money furnished him for his Journey, at play— He found there was a vessel in the harbour of Stockholm ready to sail for Cronstadt; went on board at a hazard, and in forty two hours landed at St: Petersburg— The shortest time in which a Courier can possibly come by land is six or seven days— Pahlen therefore was rewarded by an advancement in the service, for his good luck in a favourable wind— This was the commencement of his fortune— But his conduct to Paul was not to be justified, and he lost the favour of the present Emperor immediately after his accession; by going to Revel and staying there six weeks without necessity, and spending his time in nothing but drinking champaign Wine and playing Pharaoh.— Mr: Schenbom loves to talk thus of distinguished persons— He is a good scandalous chronicle— I took a short walk before dinner, and went through the Summer Gardens— Met and walked with Mr: Prevost, who told me that the Duke de Vicence had left this City on Sunday, about Noon; and expected to lodge this Night at Baron Löwenstern’s, near Riga.— On Saturday morning he had an interview with the Emperor, who had given him a box with his picture, with his own hand, saying it was a great likeness, and that he gave it not as to the Ambassador, but as a token of his particular friendship— He embraced him several times; bade him Adieu in the most affectionate manner, and even shed tears— Prevost said the Duke was much affected by the numerous marks of esteem and regret shewn him at his departure. and they were well merited— He lived here in a style of princely magnificence; and he was one of the most accomplished gentlemen in his manners that I ever knew— His civilities and attentions were always obliging, and without pretension or affectation— His personal disposition was moderate, and pacific— He had perhaps made himself too agreeable here for the purposes of his own Government— In his family it is said he was passionate and violent, and he had connections of gallantry in which he indulged
himself too much without reserve— It engrossed too much of his time— It laid him open too much to the Government here; and it occasioned scandal in a Country by no means scrupulous for the purity of their Morals— The Emperor’s presents to him at his departure are upwards of a hundred thousand rubles in value—three or four times as much as is customary to give. The more I see of this usage, the more I approve the principle adopted by the Government of the United States to prohibit altogether the acceptance by their Ministers, of any such presents— I rode with the Ladies after dinner to Catherinenhoff and on the Peterhoff road— They afterwards spent the Evening at Madame Colombi’s.

22. At length after many months of expectation, I received a letter with some news from America.— The post brought me a letter from Mr: Erving at Paris, and it announces many letters and dispatches, which are to come by the first Courier from Prince Kurakin.— It also mentions to me some news concerning myself, which by no means removes, but rather aggravates the state of painful suspense of which I must still await the issue. The French Ambassador, paid me a visit without ceremony; or as he called it incognito— Mr: Harris being with me, I introduced him to the Count— In the Evening I went with the Ladies and Charles to the French theatre, where we saw Bruis et Palaprat, Nina ou la folle par Amour and Le Pacha de Surenne, with a ballet to close— The two first of these pieces I had seen— Nina is a wretched thing, and I can hardly tell how it has kept so long possession of the stage— The music is by D’Alayrac.

23. On rising this morning I found a number of letters from my father, mother and brother at Quincy, which were brought by the Washington, Captain Brown— They contained the melancholy intelligence of the Death of my wife’s Sister, Mrs: Hellen, and of my Cousin Mrs: Norton of Weymouth— I communicated the information to Catherine first, and afterwards to Mrs Adams— It was a severe stroke to both of them; but to my wife, of dangerous import. The shock was sudden, unexpected and violent— For an hour or two Mrs: Adams was alarmingly ill, and all the rest of the day very unwell.— I was out about half an hour in the morning, and all the remainder of the day and Evening with her— Mr: Jones called on me this morning— I had invited a number of Gentlemen to dinner on Saturday; to whom I desired Mr: Smith to send excuses— Mr: Harris called in the Evening.

24. Mrs. Adams and Catherine continued both very unwell all this day— Dr: Galloway was here, and Mrs: Reineke— Although my letters from America give me occasion for much writing, I have in that respect entirely lost both yesterday and this day— In the distress and anxiety of mind occasioned by the calamities which I have just learnt of, I have not sufficient self-controul coolly to sit down and write pages of daily matter— I can scarcely keep my Journal at its station— One day of omission always doubles the duty of the next morning in this book— And the charm of a day breaks in upon the frequency if not the punctuality of my correspondence— Mr Krehmer sent me the London Courier from 19 to 26 April, where I found articles which give me great concern upon the account of my Country— They threaten War in the most unequivocal terms— I fear the British Ministry have made it unavoidable— They menace us with an “Iliad of woes” and already deny us every particle of compassion for our sufferings under them— Non nobis Dominé!— If our trial is now to come, God of Justice and of Mercy! give us Spirit to bear with fortitude, and to derive ultimate power and virtue from all the evils that they can inflict, and spare us from that woe of woes, the compassion of Britons.— Mr: Plumer was with me part of the morning, and Mr: Jones all the Evening— Mr: Etter called upon me with a letter which he had prepared for me, and one for the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, to whom he proposes to send a collection of Russian minerals.— I was again at home all day except about half an hour before dinner.

25. Mrs: Adams appeared to be better last Evening, and I hoped that the violent effect of the shock upon her Spirits occasioned by the distressing information we had received was past— But soon after going to bed she was seized with one of the severe head-aches which are Constitutional, which two successive doses of laudanum 15 and 10 drops could not compose— I waked about 2 in the morning— Soon after four called up the maids, and Catherine, though herself still very unwell rose with them— And I sent for Dr: Galloway; who came about seven— The first effect of the medicine was to increase to excess the nervous agitation, but it eventually composed; about nine she obtained the usual relief, itself very dangerous in her present situation— It produced alarming effects which continued untill the Evening. Mrs Reineke was here towards Evening and her opinions as usual are encouraging— My own anxiety is great— Dr: Galloway was here a second time soon after noon, and thinks like Mrs: Reineke— I had visits from Mr Navarro, Mr: Montréal and Mr: Harris— Wrote
in the course of the day very little— Walk’d in the morning through the Summer Gardens; and after dinner with Charles to the Corner of the Winter-Palace— We met and spoke to General Pardo and the Chevalier Brancia; and afterwards Count and Countess Litta— At the close of the Evening Mrs Adams appeared to be better.— The General of the Jesuits paid me a visit.

26. I have turned my Cabinet into a temporary bed-chamber for myself, and slept in it last Night— Mrs Adams had a good Night and continued all this day better, though still excessively weak. Catherine Johnson is also better— Mr: Everett and Mr Gray dined abroad— I went this morning to the parade— There were not so many troops out as last Sunday— The Uhlan Regiment was not on the ground— They are said to be gone to the frontiers— The weather was at high summer heat, and the Infantry were in their summer dress—white linen pantaloons and shoes— While we were at dinner there was a thunder shower, which lasted about two hours, after which it cleared off, cool and windy— In my Evening walk I overtook and walked with General Pardo, Chevalier Brancia, and Count Serge Soltykoff— Mr: Harris and Mr: Woodward paid me morning visits— I wrote to the Secretary of State; and read Massillon’s Discourse on the Duty of the Priesthood to set a good example, and Robinson’s Character of Christ, Sections 19. and 20.— Mr: Montréal was here this morning while we were at Breakfast.

27. Mr: Harris called upon me this morning; and I had also a visit from Mr: Plummer— He had a letter from Captain Larcom at Revel; containing a paragraph respecting the letters I had sent by Mr: Lohman which made it necessary for me to write and request further information of Mr: Grammann— I wrote part of this morning— As much as I could— But only half finished a letter— After dinner I rode with Catherine and Charles to Catherinenhoff, and walked there— Mr: Etter called in the Evening, to make some further inquiries; respecting the collection of Minerals, which he proposes sending to America— Mrs: Adams does not yet venture abroad.

28. Morning visits from Mr: Navarro and Mr: Harris, who told me of the dispatches received by the Russian Government from Count Pahlen, and from Mr: Daschkoff, to the 19th. of March, and the substance of their contents as related to him by Mr: Borel— I went to Mr: Etter’s house, and inspected his assortment of minerals, which he intends to send to America— After dinner I attended the exhibition of the Students at the Jesuits College, from 6 O’Clock untill 9. I had much curiosity to attend it, from the reputation of the Jesuits schools, and to compare their mode of education with ours— If I can find the time, I will give an account of this examination in a letter to one of my friends— I am sorry I cannot introduce it here— But I have not the time— The performances were in French, Latin and Russian, the last of which I of course did not understand— The young men and boys, maintained Theses of Philosophy and Mathematics in the syllogistic form against the objections of several of the Auditory— One of the objectors was Count Maistre— The students are not always effectually prepared to answer the arguments urged against them; and they were sometimes assisted and even prompted by their instructors— This form of examination is however a very strong test of their progress. They also explained, analysed and translated passages of Virgil, recited some rules of Russian Grammar, and answered various questions relative to the use of the Globes— The Hall was about the size of the Philosophy chamber at Cambridge— The company about 70 or 80 persons; ladies and Gentlemen— The students about forty from 12 to 19 or 20 years of age.— Countess Tolstoy and her Daughter, and Madame Bacounin were there— Also General Watzdorf and Mr: Navarro— After it was finished I took an hour’s walk— Home, between ten and eleven at Night— There is at present no darkness.

29. Knowing that there were a great number of letters for me which had been brought from America by Mr: Erving, and which were to be expected within a few days, I was very desirous to have got through the answers to those I received last Week, before this new supply should come to hand— But I had been able only to write a dispatch, and one letter to my brother, and had begun a letter to my father, which the interruptions of visitors prevented me from completing this morning.— Mr Jones, Mr: Plummer and Mr Dana were here— Then a book binder, and then I went to look at some plate advertised for sale— I had not time left for my usual walk— After dinner, as we were preparing for a ride, Mr: Labensky, the Russian Consul General in France called upon me, and delivered the letters and packets which had been delivered to him for me, by Mr: Russel at Paris— There were four dispatches from the Department of State, three packets of pamphlets and newspapers—and twenty-three letters to me; but none to Mrs Adams or Catherine to their great disappointment— There was a letter and a packet for Mr Harris, the last of which by mistake was opened here—it contained only pamphlets, of the Laws. I had one letter from Mr: Hellen, with the account of his wife’s death, and a melancholy, but I fear too well founded anticipation of his own— Mr Harris himself called, and I delivered to him the letter address’d to him— I was engaged all the remainder of the Evening, and untill past one O’Clock in the morning, in reading my dispatches and letters— In saying there were no letters for my wife, I meant from her own family—there were several from my Mother, and from our children—

30. My dispatches and letters from America have in the present as in other instances cost me the repose of one Night— Their contents on this occasion so deeply affect my personal feelings and the state of my family that there was more than usual cause for the loss of my sleep— And I had not finished the filing and assorting of my letters this morning when a succession of visits from Messrs Navarro, Fisher and Moses, Harris, Woodward and Captain Burnham, engaged me untill dinner time— I dined at Mr: Raimbert’s; with Mr: Navarro, Mr: Harris, Mr: Boucher, Mr: Woodward, and the Gentlemen of my family— After dinner I attended the second day’s examination of the students at the Jesuits College. It lasted nearly four hours and turned altogether upon Mathematics and Arithmetic— The first Classes answered upon Algebra, Trigonometry, Conic Sections; calculation of eclipses and Geometry—the smaller boys upon multiplication division, and the rule of three— The exhibition was tedious to the extreme, and intelligible scarcely to a person of the auditory— But it indicates a much greater attention to mathematical studies than is paid in our Country, which is natural, where the military profession is almost the only one for which the young men are educated— The company was nearly the same as before— I walk’d home, by my usual grand tour round the Fontanka and by the river Quay— It was almost eleven at Night when I reached home— I received this morning the notice of a launch for Saturday Morning.

31. The loss of one Night’s rest commonly occasions a large encroachment upon the studious hours of the next morning— I rose late this day, and from Breakfast time had scarcely leisure enough to bring up the arrears of my journal— I had visits from Mr: Harris, Mr Fisher and Captain Hayes, and I took my usual morning’s walk— On the Fontanka, near the Bridge through which the Canal joins the river I met the Emperor walking— As he approached me, he said; Monsieur Adams, il y a cent ans que je ne vous ai vu, and coming up took and shook me with great cordiality by the hand— After some common observations upon the weather which has been very fine, which this day was cold and autumnal, and which he thought would yet come to snow, before the end of the month, Russian style, he asked me whether I intended to take a house in the Country this Summer— I said no— That I had for some time had such an intention but had given it up— And why so, said he?— I was hesitating upon an answer, when he relieved me from embarrassment by saying [“]Peut-être sont ce des considerations de Finance”— As he said it in perfect good humour, and with a smile, I replied in the same manner— Mais— Sire— Elles y sont pour une bonne part— Fort bien; said he—vous avez raison— Il faut toujours proportionner la dépense à la recette— A maxim worthy of an Emperor, though few Emperors practice upon it— He then asked me if I had received any late news from America— I said I had— He replied that he also had lately received some very interesting despatches from Count Pahlen, which had given him much pleasure— He asked how our affairs stood with England— I said they had a very hostile appearance, and that the English Journals were threatening us with the last extremities; but that my own letters from America did not appear to expect that a War would ensue— It has however said he very much that appearance—at least if we believe the French Journals— But, au reste—he added, we know how much the Moniteur is to be believed; and that certain deductions are to be made from whatever that contains— I said to be sure— People were very apt to publish as fact, what they had an interest and a wish to believe— On this he made me his usual parting bow, or rather military salute by raising his hand to his hat and pursued his walk— I continued mine and returned home to dinner— Soon after 6 in the Evening, I went and attended the third and last day’s examination of the pupils at the Jesuit’s school— The Examination was of the four Classes, and being upon subjects more easily comprehended than the sublimer mathematics of last Evening I was much better entertained with it— French and latin Grammar— Geography, Mythology— Prosody— Passages from Virgil’s Eclogues, and from Gresset’s French translation of them— Rhetoric; with a recitation and illustration by analysis of Massillon’s funeral eulogy upon Turenne and Cicero’s Oration pro Rege Dejotara, furnished the materials for the examination— The exercises closed by what we should call at our Colleges a Conference, upon the respective merit of the Infantry, Cavalry, Artillery, and light troops for military service— Four of the young men delivered discourses on the superior merit, which each of these modes of service might claim; and a fifth opened the subject to the Auditory, and sat as umpire of the contest— He adjudged the palm of utility to the Infantry, assigned the next place to the Cavalry—the third to the Artillery, and regretted that he had not a fourth prize to bestow, upon the Cossacks, the Hulons, and the Hussars— The controversy was very well supported, and each of the young men delivered his part, as well as would be done by most of our College Speakers— Oratory however is less cultivated here than with us, and in that respect the
performances are inferior to ours; as in the mathematics they are much superior— The printed notice of the exercises says that the discourses of the young martial disputants were composed by themselves; but this must be taken as the Emperor takes the news in the Moniteur— After the performances were finished the prizes, (books handsomely bound) were distributed, to the Students who had excelled, by application and success—two to each Class— Their names were publicly proclaimed by one of the fathers; and the Minister of public Instruction gave them the books.— It was about 10 at Night when all was finished. On returning home I found Mr: Harris and Mr: Jones with the Ladies— They remained here untill near Midnight.

Day. Its only difference from that of the last Month is occasioned by the more frequent interruption of visitors— As there is no darkness, I make my principal walk now after dinner— And occasionally walk also before breakfast in the morning— The labour of my life at present is writing— Its principal amusement is reading— But I have so much and so frequent occasion to write, that my time for reading is very much abridged— I have scarcely any leisure and hardly an hour to give to any favourite trifling, a Passion which I have too much propensity to indulge— My time slips away with so much regularity that I find at the end of every month that I have written very nearly the same quantity as the month preceding— Of this Journal, the public and private letter books a page in three days— Amounting to about one folio page every day— If the matter were better, the quantity would be enough.
